code: test_output(   "test_name", # name of check   "PASS", # result of check, one of 'PASS', 'FAIL', 'WARNING'   paste0("'", filename, "' does not contain any special characters."), # feedback message for user, avoid HTML, keep to a simple string   "https://dfe-analytical-services.github.io/analysts-guide/", # optional URL for guidance, can just not include as will default to NA   verbose = FALSE # whether to print messages to console   stop_on_error = FALSE # whether to stop execution and throw error if FAIL, and throw warning if WARNING )

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: [DEVELOPMENT] package designed provide documentation reusable code supporting data standards explore education statistics (EES) platform. current form single source truth checks steadily evolved years, initial R code replacing manual checking CSV files Excel, screening report generator using rmarkdown, R Shiny app, right fully documented R package three main use cases: Providing logic behind data screener R Shiny app, used check files upload Using logic within EES plumber API implementation, screening uploads service directly Analysts using R functions within pipelines pre-emptive quality assurance package contains: core screen_csv() function, built screen_dfs(), screen_filenames() constituent individual checks, well related wrapper function screen_zip() Data objects containing required, optional, acceptable values use within explore education statistics Functions generate test data Example datasets aid testing demonstration Additional functions aid screening / preparing data EES

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: want generate larger files testing , can use generate_test_dfs() function create files number time periods, locations, filters indicators. want go bigger, combine dfeR package, pass vectors Parliamentary Constituencies. following example creates example data metadata pair data set just 6 million rows. Formula calculate rows : length(years) * length(pcon_codes) * (5 ^ num_filters)
code: files <- eesyscreener::generate_test_dfs(   years = 2013:2015,    pcon_names = "Sheffield Central",    pcon_codes = "E14000919",    num_filters = 2,    num_indicators = 3 )  # Data and metadata are returned in a list, to extract: df <- files$data df_meta <- files$meta # Get a data frame of all Parliamentary Constituencies in England pcons <- dfeR::fetch_pcons(countries = "England")  beefy <- eesyscreener::generate_test_dfs(   years = c(1980:2025),   pcon_codes = pcons$pcon_code,   pcon_names = pcons$pcon_name,   num_filters = 3,   num_indicators = 45,   verbose = TRUE )  # Then to create CSVs, use duckplyr as it's a lot faster than base R # roughly ~20 seconds compared to ~6 minutes duckplyr::compute_csv(beefy$data, "beefy_data.csv") write.csv(beefy$meta, "beefy_data.meta.csv", row.names = FALSE)
